triples.name: Misinformation
triples.relevance: The paper investigates how misinformation is shared on social media platforms and what drives users to share false news.

triples.name: Social media
triples.relevance: The paper studies social media platforms as the primary context where habitual sharing behaviors develop and false news spreads.

triples.name: Habit
triples.relevance: The paper proposes that information sharing on social media is driven by habits formed through reward-based learning, not just cognitive deficits or bias.

triples.name: Reinforcement learning
triples.relevance: The paper uses reward-based learning principles to explain how social media platforms train users to share information through engagement metrics.

triples.name: Confirmation bias
triples.relevance: The paper challenges confirmation bias (related to partisan bias) as a primary driver of misinformation sharing, showing habits matter more.
